lexUnit.name: startle.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: cause to feel sudden shock or alarm.

sentence.text: What had startled him was that she had a sister , Sandra Riverton , who had worked for INCUBUS in Suffolk .
It startled her that he should know this much when she had tried so hard to be circumspect in making her enquiries .
What had startled the dogs whose frenzied barking had disturbed the sheep ?
We climbed as near to the base of the cliff as possible , and startled an Arctic fox which trotted off unhurriedly .
It always startles our other guests when he visits .
It startled her when Simon laughed .
His question startled her .
The photograph sprang to her eyes and startled her .
There the presence of the past startled her , not altogether pleasantly .
The girl 's voice in her ear startled her ; it was so clear and so close .
A shout from above startled him .
He looked up as though the question had startled him .
I had been reaching up to put packets and tins into one of the wall cupboards , but this startled me into turning .
` William , you startled me ! "
The statement startled no one .
â€œ Sorry if I startled you .
Phillario , however , is startled by the sight of Mira :
They were all startled by his reaction .
Constance was startled by Miss Hatherby 's appearance when she arrived at the Hall .
This way the badgers are never startled by the sound of my movements
However , he was somewhat startled by the sober determination with which she spoke of leaving home .
She was jumpy and had at one point been startled by her own shadow .
She was startled by his calm reply .
A grey squirrel , spry after its winter sleep , startled Ben by scampering across his path .
The voice startled her out of her reverie and she turned to see Candy in the doorway , her pert features anxious .
The stories startled him and stung him .
Startled by his sudden , critical observation , she made a small gesture of dismissal .
